prompt: <description>**Part 1: A Rectangular Metal Bar with Two Circular Holes on Opposite Ends** **1.1 Sketching the Main Profile of the Rectangular Bar** 1. Create a new coordinate system with euler angles and translation vector all set to 0 degrees and 0 units respectively. 2. Begin by drawing the first face of the part, which will form the main profile of the rectangular bar. 3. On this face, create a loop consisting of four curves: - Line 1: Begin at (0, 0) and end at (0.224, 0). - Line 2: Begin at (0.224, 0) and end at (0.224, 0.638). - Arc 1: Begin at (0.224, 0.638), with its midpoint at (0.112, 0.75), and end at (0, 0.638). - Line 3: Begin at (0, 0.638) and end at (0, 0). The loop is now closed. **1.2 Creating the Circular Holes** 1. Create a second face on the same plane as the first face. Directly above the midpoint of the bar and centered on that vertical axis, sketch a circle using the coordinates: - Center: (0.112, 0.375) - Radius: 0.0779 2. Create a third face on the same plane as the first face. Directly below the midpoint of the bar and centered on that vertical axis, sketch a circle using the coordinates: - Center: (0.112, 0.638) - Radius: 0.0779 **1.3 Extruding the Main Profile and Holes** 1. Set the sketch scaling parameter to 0.75. 2. Extrude the entire sketch (faces, loops, and curves) along the normal vector to a depth of 0.0779 units (towards the normal), and set the opposite normal depth to 0 units. 3. This concludes the first part, which composes a rectangular metal bar of dimensions 0.75 x 0.75 x 0.0779 units with two circular holes on opposite ends. Please proceed with creating subsequent parts according to the outlined structure and recipe provided. Be precise in referencing the shapes, dimensions, and coordinates, so that the final CAD assembly follows the given specifications.</description>
